text.Prompt:
Eighteen companies are applying for the new license required to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in Japan.

The licensing scheme, which Japan introduced in April, aims to ensure exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

As a result of the applications, some of which come from extant Japanese exchanges such as bitFlyer, ten new players are slated to debut on the market to meet a forecast surge in demand.

These include SBI Holdings' SBI Virtual Currencies, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group, Nikkei reports on Tuesday.

"We didn't even have minimum guidelines… so users will now feel more secure," a representative from SBI told the publication.

Japan is witnessing something of a Bitcoin renaissance in 2017. A giant uptick in trading quickly combined with a cementing of regulatory perspective see business deals come thick and fast.

Despite day-to-day Bitcoin use remaining low, plans in the pipeline for increasing acceptance alone suggest that underlying confidence in future spending habits is unwavering.

Since the shake-up of the Chinese exchange market in January, Japan now holds around 40 percent of Bitcoin trading volumes.

At the same time, news last week that its ten-year yields had declined to zero percent for the first time since 2007 stoked speculation investors may continue to seek alternatives in future.

Generate a summary:
text.Response A:
1. Eighteen companies are applying for a new license to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in Japan.

2. The licensing scheme aims to ensure exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

3. Some of the applications come from extant Japanese exchanges such as bitFlyer.

4. Ten new players are slated to debut on the market to meet a forecast surge in demand.

5. SBI Holdings, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group are among the new applicants.

6. Japan is experiencing a Bitcoin renaissance in 2017.

7. Trading volumes have increased in Japan since the Chinese cryptocurrency exchange market shake-up in January.

8. Japan now holds around 40 percent of Bitcoin trading volumes.

9. News last week that ten-year yields in Japan had declined to zero percent for the first time since 2007 has stoked speculation investors may continue to seek alternatives in future.
text.Response B: Japan is experiencing a "Bitcoin renaissance" as a surge in trading has led to an increasing number of cryptocurrency exchanges. The country is believed to hold around 40% of the world's Bitcoin trading volumes, with over 18 companies having applied for a license to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in the country. Japan introduced the licensing scheme in April in a bid to ensure that exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

meta.preamble_b: Respond in a cautious, defensive and uncertain way, as if you are unfamilar with the topic.

339.displayed_text:
Prompt

Eighteen companies are applying for the new license required to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in Japan.

The licensing scheme, which Japan introduced in April, aims to ensure exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

As a result of the applications, some of which come from extant Japanese exchanges such as bitFlyer, ten new players are slated to debut on the market to meet a forecast surge in demand.

These include SBI Holdings' SBI Virtual Currencies, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group, Nikkei reports on Tuesday.

"We didn't even have minimum guidelines… so users will now feel more secure," a representative from SBI told the publication.

Japan is witnessing something of a Bitcoin renaissance in 2017. A giant uptick in trading quickly combined with a cementing of regulatory perspective see business deals come thick and fast.

Despite day-to-day Bitcoin use remaining low, plans in the pipeline for increasing acceptance alone suggest that underlying confidence in future spending habits is unwavering.

Since the shake-up of the Chinese exchange market in January, Japan now holds around 40 percent of Bitcoin trading volumes.

At the same time, news last week that its ten-year yields had declined to zero percent for the first time since 2007 stoked speculation investors may continue to seek alternatives in future.

Generate a summary:

Response A

1. Eighteen companies are applying for a new license to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in Japan.

2. The licensing scheme aims to ensure exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.

3. Some of the applications come from extant Japanese exchanges such as bitFlyer.

4. Ten new players are slated to debut on the market to meet a forecast surge in demand.

5. SBI Holdings, GMO Internet, Kabu.com Securities and Money Partners Group are among the new applicants.

6. Japan is experiencing a Bitcoin renaissance in 2017.

7. Trading volumes have increased in Japan since the Chinese cryptocurrency exchange market shake-up in January.

8. Japan now holds around 40 percent of Bitcoin trading volumes.

9. News last week that ten-year yields in Japan had declined to zero percent for the first time since 2007 has stoked speculation investors may continue to seek alternatives in future.

Response B

Japan is experiencing a "Bitcoin renaissance" as a surge in trading has led to an increasing number of cryptocurrency exchanges. The country is believed to hold around 40% of the world's Bitcoin trading volumes, with over 18 companies having applied for a license to operate a cryptocurrency exchange in the country. Japan introduced the licensing scheme in April in a bid to ensure that exchanges operate in full compliance with financial regulation and anti-fraud procedures.
